div.head: TO THE HIGH COVRT OF PARLIAMENT.
div.p:

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE WILLIAM EARLE OF BEDFORD, and his Honourable friends Adventurers in the great levell of FENNES.
div.p:
IF I Å¿hould now be Å¿ilent, I Å¿hould not know how to frame my Å¿elf an excuÅ¿e: Having heretofore beene a Å¿ervant to the Right Honourable, the Earle of Bedford, & his Honorable friends in the drayning: And well obÅ¿erving how one Mr Hill who had then power put into his hands, did begin to go a wrong way to work upon Wisbeech River; which Å¿o Å¿oone as I perceived, I made it knowne, and although
Å¿ome money was expended that way by him before I could prevent it, yet I Å¿aved them a 1000. pounds; And can I now be Å¿ilent? when by Å¿peaking I may not onely Å¿ave 1000. but many thouÅ¿ands, in preventing the purÅ¿uance of a deÅ¿perate deÅ¿Å¿gne, which the Honorable Committee for the Fens have ordered to be printed, that whoÅ¿oever it concernes might make exceptions againÅ¿t it; Å¿ilence in this caÅ¿e might give the Parliament and your LordÅ¿hips juÅ¿t cauÅ¿e to approve thereof, which promiÅ¿e Å¿o faire, and to which none could take exceptions, though invited to it. I have therefore with all faithfulneÅ¿Å¿e, briefly laid open the danger, which in all humility I preÅ¿ent unto your LordÅ¿hips, that the danger being diÅ¿covered, which before lay hid under faire promiÅ¿es and prete â¢â¢â¢ may be avoided: And now whether theÅ¿e my ãââã may here prove acceptable or no, I know not; Yet however, I have declared my opinion, and left it extant, that future times may witneÅ¿Å¿e that the danger was diÅ¿covered. For my owne part I am confident, that if this deÅ¿igne be purÅ¿ued, what I have now written, one day by coÅ¿tly experience will be found to be true.
